posts.com:
>>9640282
[cont]

The translation introduces a glitch at some point mid way through the game and you'll probably need the help of savestates and/or the guide to get out of it as the player gets sent into a graphically glitched area. Also don't use the "exp counter" patch, it doesn't work.
Also the end boss is really challenging, I could only beat it with the following strategy (the strategy told in the guide is terrible): go to the glitchy point mentioned just above, there is a computer that lets you re-distribute your stats. Forget about agility, for the 2 guys focus on attack, for the girl on wisdom (magical attack power). The protag should have the psycho sword, while the girl should spam Thunder (and not Thunder3, the MP cost isn't worth the difference). Use Psyshell at the start of the fight for increased def. Forget about the robot, use it for healing items and then let it die. Have as many Vitaron and Brainer items as you can in the inventory.

Not a bad game per se but I hope you're ready for a lot of grind, cryptic puzzles, and an unfinished (even glitchy) translation.

Other tips:
-The battle msg speed is VERY slow by default: press select in the menu to remedy that.
-Spells not specified in the FAQ:
Wall: increase def for a single character
Inji: increase chance of escaping battle
-A common trick for RPGs of the time: you can avoid battle in the overworld by opening the menu and closing it every 4-5 steps. This also seems to work in dungeons, however dungeons also have set battles on some tiles you can not avoid.

>>9642476
I give it point because I think the difficulty of the western NES version was spot on for me yes, but not just that. Exploration and possible unlinearilty, the adventure mechanics, god tier music, still images of enemies that look dynamic, characters and story that managed to draw me in despite the low amount of text, and much more.
People in the west only praise DQ1 as "father of the JRPG", but really most of those other RPGs owe as much (if not more) to 2 than to 1; so there is that too, being the first doing so many things for the genre. In the DQ anniversary doc on youtube they do acknowledge DQ2's legacy.

Few examples of why I think DQ2 is well designed:
- the allies and the way they join the party. Everything is made to make you realize they were going through their own adventures of their own while you were. This gives them weight and personality and puts everyone on the same level. How many RPGs have each character put on the same level of importance like that? Certainly not DQ3.
- The way towns work like hubs. You usually use the same town in between several small quests; either that or there is a good reason to come back to the town later on. This makes the world feel organic, real; vs the tired routine "each area is composed of one town, one dungeon, clear that, reach next area, repeat" which DQ3 started.
- The adventure elements, namely the treasure hunting; DQ2 probably started the "you must find X number of magical key items as a goal" trope for jRPGs (unless you count Zelda as an RPG), but unlike later/other use of that trope in which the key item is merely a meaningless token for denoting that you beat a dungeon; here you must go through adventure game mechanics to acquire them, acquire clues, solve puzzle, beat dungeons too sure but not only, and almost each one is acquired differently. Again this makes the items and the world feel real and you can imagine what happened to each item to get to the point that they are now.

It's true that it can feel overwhelming, but at the same time it is well designed and designed in such a way that you are likely to stumble on the easier areas first.

IIRC one of the NPCs tell you to go East or that Tantagel is east or something like that, and looking at the world map you're very likely to stumble on it first as it's located next to Lianport.

Then, once that area is cleared you're likely to find either Osterfair and Beran (if not by boat, by using the monoliths) which are the next logical destinations; and going to either place before the other doesn't really matter.

And in the end, Tuhn is the hardest place to find, it's also where the enemies are some of the strongest (pre-final area) and where you can get one of the best pieces of armor.

Meanwhile in DQ3, it's MUCH easier to stumble on harder areas early on. On my first playthrough I remember one of the first places I found by boat was Jipang and I got absolutely assblasted by the enemies in the cave there.

posts.com:
This one was pretty fast to go through as well

>Doraemon - Giga Zombie no Gyakushuu (Doraemon - The Revenge of Giga Zombie)

Another game in the pile of "obvious DQ clone", but another pleasant surprise. The game is based on the Doraemon licence, a series of manga and anime I'm only vaguely familiar with (it aired for a short time two decades ago in my country).
In some ways it is reminiscent of the Mother series, the game starts in a realistic modern day (for the time) area, in this case Japan, before venturing into other worlds and eras. You play as yourself accompanying Doraemon in his search of allies (who come and go, but who actually leave their inventory behind when they do!), you enter your name and your sex, and there is a different character for boys and girls (this came out after DQ4). The story doesn't take itself too seriously, each area has its own side plot and feel like they could be an episode from a series.
The musics are really good often sounding upbeat and joyous, great sounding drums and bass, and varied enough. Graphics are good enough but nothing extraordinary, some of the enemies don't look very good; but they are very varied with lot's of different locations.
Some interesting mechanics: there is a party chat you can use to remember what to do next and there is a seperate bag for inventory items (which can contain up to 100 items!), two things the DQ series would only introduce later on. Money is used to buy items (but not equipment, which is only found) but it is also used to cast spells and you only earn money from fights once you get back to a town.
Spells are treated like inventory items, so you can assign them to whomever, with the added downside of clogging the inventories quickly. However most spells don't work on the field (the cure spell even got consumed when I tried, so don't do that!)
[cont]
posts.filename: Doraemon - Giga Zombie no Gyakushuu (Doraemon - The Revenge of Giga Zombie)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646547
[cont]


Difficulty is very easy, there is basically no grinding whatsoever and if you really needed it, leveling up just once makes a big difference. When a character dies, he's back to 1HP once the fight is over. If the entire party dies, you're back to the last save location (in a town) but you lose neither progress nor money. So the game is very lenient and just wants you to have a good time; but you still don't want to die in combat (no reviving) and enemies remain strong, so despite being a leniant game with no grinding, combat still manages to remain engaging.
On the downside, only a few defensive spells work at all during boss fights, few combat items did too; so it's all just the attack command against them. Also enemies in random encounters get quickly repetitive as you fight the same 3 enemies over and over in each area; although most areas are short enough it doesn't become too much a burden. You also get a Repel spell that actually works if you're tired of it. Enemies often behaved similarly too and rarely used spells so there were little incentive to prioritize targets.

All in all, a simple and easy but quirky and fun experience that managed to suck me in with its offbeat world. The game doesn't overstay its welcome either (around 15 hours).

>Maharaja

Adventure-RPG game from 1989 published by Sunsoft. It mixes elements from command based adventure games, going around still first person screens, talking to NPCs, solving puzzles, and RPG elements with random encounters, turned based fights, shops, equipment and spells. If you know Cleopatra no Mahou, it plays exactly like that, except that in Cleopatra the RPG elements are light and the adventure elements more developed, but in Maharaja it is the contrary.
The adventure elements are pretty simple, there is the occasional item puzzle and NPC to talk to in order to progress, but there is nothing that should make you require a guide. Along the game you can buy better equipment and acquire many spells, which you don't get right away on level up as you need to backtrack to town and to Shiva's temple to learn them.
The game's main pro is its graphics, environments are colourful and varied. Enemies look good and have various animations (idle, attacking, etc), and musics are pretty good as well. The story revolves around Hindu religious elements but sadly still boils down to "demon lord wants to conquer the world".
[cont]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9657829
[cont]
The main flaw is how repetitive and samey the dungeons are. There are 3 towers, 2 forests and a final castle. All 3 towers use the same design with the rooms and layout being identical in all floors of all 3 towers and only the palette changing. The 2 forests use the same visual design as well. Finally, navigating the final castle can easily get confusing. As you go around still screens, you never know what angle the next screen will use, for instance you may enter a room to the east and find yourself facing north on the next screen. This leads to easily turning in round on yourself, triggering random encounters in the process, just to get your bearings.
Also while there is a spell to warp to known places, there isn't one to exit a dungeon, so you'll find yourself backtracking a lot, with the point of views making it look like you're literally walking backwards.
Grinding a bit is necessary, but very fast, and you'll find that just 1-2 levels gained make a huge difference. The game isn't very long otherwise (around 8 hours, which is still longer than Cleopatra).

Conclusion: a hybrid mix of adventure and RPG elements that excels at neither, but fun nonetheless if your expectations aren't too high. It managed to draw me in which it somewhat more original setting and quality graphics.

>Sugoro Quest - Dice no Senshitachi (The 100 World Story - The Tales on a Watery Wilderness)

RPG-Board game, a unique concept. As with board game logic you go around the board turn after turn, except the game is an RPG: you go around fighting encounters (random and pre-set), go through sidequests, in order to gain experience, level up, and buy equipment and spells, so you can tackle on the dragon serving as final boss of the board.
Graphics use very simple lines and colouring, but are charming because of it. Enemies look comical and are animated.
You fight against the clock, as there is a pre-set number of turns, and dying only puts you back to square one. However, you make up your own rules, from number of turns to number of players to random encounter appearance rate; and this is where the game shines. It must be played with between 2 and 4 players, as the controller is passed around, but any player can be AI controlled too. Then, you may decide to either cooperate with the other players, even going as far as teaming up to move and fight together (regrouping and splitting whenever you feel like, but also sharing gear and items), or you may decide to play against each others, and you can even fight the other players if you meet them on the field.
Simply using 2 players working together will make the game much easier however.
There are three boards, three different stories, but they all basically boil down to the same thing, with only the size of the board changing, though you may get an occasional "plot twist", which can randomly change a scenario.
posts.filename: Sugoro Quest - Dice no Senshitachi (The 100 World Story - The Tales on a Watery Wilderness)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9657856
[cont]
The sidequests you can trigger are also semi-randomized but you will quickly find the same ones repeating. In fact the game itself is very repetitive: try to find the quickest methods to acquire exp and gold (quests), then buy the strongest equipment and go kill the dragon. Though as with board game logic, you may randomly stumble on something that makes you lose exp or even all of your money.
One flaw is that at first it is hard to understand the turn logic (number of steps allowed etc) and for instance making the wrong choice in the command menu in a town can easily cost you a turn.
Each board only takes 30-60 minutes to complete so it is a very short game, but replayability and rules changes give it more length. Playing alone isn't much, but I can easily imagine it being a fun party game.

>>9653791
Video game sequels had to be somewhat experimental back in the day in order to test the waters on want the general public wants from a video game sequel.
This is why Lost Levels wasn't localized and we got Mario 2 instead.
It's also why Zelda 2 is a radical departure from Zelda 1.
The thing about experiments is that they're not always successful.
Some people liked Castlevania II and appreciated the differences it brought to the table. Most didn't. This is why Castlevania III was a lot more like the first game, and the "metroidvania" concept was shelved for another ten years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622353
Sometimes it's possible, but it depends on how each patch was constructed. If one or more of them start moving data around that conflicts with the other patches it'll break. If there's no documentation about it then the only way to know for sure would be to try it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9622353
Use Lunar IPS and make sure the "Create a log file" option is ticked, then check the log files and see if that no two hacks replaces the same addresses (offset + size)

in most cases if there are is no overlap then it should be compatible, unless as pointed out, one of the hacks moved data around and a change in another hack still thinks the data is in the original place.

So you enable the "fast" ROM read speed (the speed used by almost if not all commercial games), you read some data from ROM and if returned values are not what you expect you are using a piece of shit cart.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9641495
>is using C instead of assembly to 8~16bits video game still a bad idea?
it's not a baaaaad idea, but you are never going to get away with Pure C unless you're making an RPG or something not processor intensive. there's just so little memory and processing power and you are super tied to the hardware, and the overhead that C requires is going to suck precious resources. there's no way around it.
a going theory on NESdev is to use some C for the overarching logic and sprinkle in raw ASM where the performance is needed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9650240
Castlevania 3's US release leaves a ton of data untouched as the memory was expanded drastically. It's all technically bank switching background graphics and not pure sprite data (otherwise the rest of the game would become a flickering mess) which means game performance doesn't take any hits. The downside being it takes up a massive amount of space only the MMC5 could effectively handle, along the line of around 16 banks. The plan going forward would be to render a much larger rotating structure with more detail.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
FFVII has such a weird look for how much hype it got for its graphics—I don't mean it in a bad way though. It looks so distinctive, and very much a product of its time.
Most polygons are untextured and only have Gouraud shading. The chibi 3D models showed this weird transition from old FF to new FF. The whole style of the game is in this limbo of sorts between FFVI and full Nomura. There's already been enough said about the cutscenes and pre-rendered BGs, but today they got some vintage quality of that early 3D look like DKC, and I like small strange details in them like that My Bloody Valentine poster—areas from PS games like RE2 are full of mysterious references like these.
Overall, it looks imperfect, but that surprisingly gives it unique charm and soul, and makes it more interesting to look at than far more polished, generic-looking FFVIII (IMO).

>>9657674
Yes. It has to do with pixel clock. Like most time keeping that's based on UTC. Tokyo is to the east, UTC+9, so pixels are shifted 9 to the right. NY is to the west, UTC-5, so pixels are shifted 5 to the left. Only in glorious bongistan PALland do you get pixels in the correct position. True story.

I like Seymour for what he is.
He's certainly not a good enough character to be the main antagonist, but he's a great recurring villain.
It's interesting how he's thinking and acting on an entirely different scale than every other character in the game.
I also like that you can use a turn to call him a piece of shit mid-battle. That's fucking great, every Final Fantasy game should do that.

I never felt that the characters were written too irrationally.
Auron has his own plan, Tidus doesn't know what's going on, Rikku is trying her best, and everyone else has a martyr complex the size of Arizona.
There are a few scenes that are played for melodrama but nothing was a dealbreaker for me.

>Random Encounters
I don't know why this is such a big deal to people.
Does seeing the enemy on the map and bumping into them before combat really just light your soul on fire? I've never cared that much.

>Bad writing
The Japanese version has very solid writing.
I haven't seen the English version in a while but from my memory it isn't particularly worse than other JRPG translations.
>Unskippable cutscenes
There are a few boss fights in this game that use Petrify and Death status effects, and unless you keep anti-stone anti-death equips on 100% of the time there's a good chance you'll have to go through them more than once.
Other than that I can't think of any situation you would want to skip a cutscene in this game.
>Save points
It's 2023. If this is a dealbreaker for you, use save states.
>Bad tutorials
By this I'm assuming you're talking about the in battle tutorials where the characters give advice to each other?
Those end in Mi'ihen and I thought they were cute. In total, they're like, two minutes of the game, max.
>Awful character design
I think Yuna, Rikku, and Lulu have awesome character designs, as do all the summons.
Auron and Kimahri look pretty cool too imo.
Tidus and Wakka are fashion rejects, but in a kind of lovable way that makes sense for their characters.
>Weird voices
I can only recommend you play the Japanese version or one of the many undubs.

>Other than that I can't think of any situation you would want to skip a cutscene in this game.
Not him, but I remember restarting a few times to win that first blitzball match and the unskippable intro cutscene was annoying. Besides that, why would you want to skip cutscenes in a story-driven RPG?
I don't mind it as a QoL improvement though, especially if it comes with a pause function. Some games just slap skip on the start button without telling you so, when it acts as pause everywhere else in the game and that's stupid and counter-intuitive. A perfect way to do this is to have the start button pause the cutscene and then offer you an option to skip or resume it, like in MGS4 or the Yakuza series, for example. That should really be a standard for all games. Too bad they didn't include it in the remaster.
>I can only recommend you play the Japanese version or one of the many undubs.
Seconded. I can't bear the English dub in this game, it ruins it for me. The original voices are MUCH better. Again, I wish the remaster let you change the language without resorting to mods and file-swapping (which makes it exclusive to the PC version, too).
In general, FF dubs had a rough start in English, but every installment starting from XII onwards had a great dub. Sure, there are a few exceptions like Vanille sounding outright retarded in XIII, but for most of the time they're pretty good, even if I prefer Japanese voices overall (save for XII, the EN dub is phenomenal and I prefer it over JP).
On that note, which dub is supposed to be the main one for XVI? I feel like the English voices are going to be really strong this time, but I'll probably play the game more than once and taste both anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646192
I just finished it in Japanese for the first time; I think you'll enjoy it.
There's some neat differences in the text, I'll put them in spoilers in case you'd rather see them first hand.
In Japanese Sin is called シン (Shin), which at first appears to just be how they've decided to pronounce the English word Sin, but later on in the story when it's revealed that Sin is not actually Spira's punishment, it turns out that the true meaning of his name is 死 (death).
Yu Yevon's original name is Ebon Jew, was probably changed to avoid people thinking the game was antisemitic.
All of Lulu's dialogue is completely different. The double entendre's were all added in the dub. She mostly just calls upon the spirits to help defeat her enemies. It changes the feel of her character a lot.
As you might expect, the Al Bhed dictionary sidequest is quite different. There are still 26 dictionaries, but each one gives you several kana instead of one letter.
One thing to note is that there's a lot of dialogue that advances automatically, so if you aren't confident in your comprehension speed you might want to consider playing it in an emulator so you can pause if you want.
I have a lot of Japanese experience and I still got lost a few times when the dialogue is talking about how the 幻光虫 cause the 祈り子 to give the 召喚士 their 召喚獣 and their 異界送り. Feels like fantasy technobabble.

>>9652101
Its so fucking weird because it sets up a bunch of big moments later. For example: Yuna tells Tidus to force a laughter when he's sad. Because that's what Yuna does. Because Yuna knows she's doomed and dwelling on it will make the pilgrimage harder. So she makes herself smile and laugh even when she's feeling miserable or hopeless. Which should make you retroactively look at that scene with a sad lens. But in Macalania before the kiss Tidus gives Yuna an out. That she can run away with him to live their lives. And for the only time in the game Yuna muses on what life like that would be like before breaking down in tears and admiting she can't have the life she actually wants. Sin is a plague. She can kill it. But that means she has no future. And no amount of fake laughing will fix that.

But it also sets up another scene because in Bevelle, just before the end of the game this dialogue happens.

>Bahamut: But, you know… When it is all over…we will wake, and our dream will end. Our dream will vanish.
>Tidus: Yeah. You’ve been dreaming a long time, haven’t you?
>Bahamut: I’m sorry.
>Tidus: I’m grateful.
>Bahamut: (Vanishes)
>Yuna: About what?
>Tidus: Oh, nothing. Hey, don’t make that face! Come on! We’re going to beat Sin! Let’s see some cheer, okay?
>Yuna: You’re hiding something.
>Tidus: I’m not!
>Yuna: Really? ...You’re a bad liar, you know?

Tidus can't lie. He can't manufacture a fake laugh and he can't trick Yuna into thinking everything is fine with it isn't. Tidus is a genuine person. He wears everything on his sleeve and that laughing scene sets up how both characters function.

So you get people like >>9650341 who'll meme and say CRINGE but then when you point out the purpose of the scene and how much it sets up they'll just say YEAH BUT I DIDN'T LIKE IT. Disney tier characterization and they miss it.

>>9638930
Its pretty decent. at the least, the puzzles in this game are slightly more complex. The story is interesting and the world building isn't bad.

there's a handful of things that are kind of stupid like Tidus's voice is annoying. John Dimaggio doing a terrible hispanic accent for some reason.

although in this game the character designs are a bit off the deep end.

the worst part about the gameplay is that while they have simplified some things, they've added so much flexibility that the game becomes way too easy. like you can change how you get your limit break which makes it easy to set it in a way where you will constantly get it and use it.

Plus it doesn't take a whole lot of grinding to get weapons that can break the damage cap, which makes the game an absolute breeze, especially with the summons

things like the laughing scene have been memed to death, as a supposed example of bad voice acting. which it isn't in context. but in general it does go to show that a Japanese sci-fi fantasy game being voice acted probably isn't the best idea because of some of the goofy shit that people try to say with a straight and serious performance.

It deals with some pretty mature things which is interesting.

overall it's not bad, but it is far different from the other final fantasy games and that may put you off if you are a fan.

The music is great but I don't feel like it says iconic as some of the previous games.

Blitzball is a better minigame than XIs shitty card game. But if you get Jecht Shot then it becomes painfully easy. Tidus, swim, Jecht Shot repeat. You are winner!

So because of all of that I can only recommend that you play it because whether or not you love it or hate it will depends solely on you because it is very divisive in that way.

at the least, you can spend the game staring at Lulu's TITS MASSIVE MILKERS

posts.com: Probably Fire Emblem GBA. It has an excellent tutorial for anyone new to SRPGs and is one of the best games on the system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
SRPG is a Japanese abbreviation (of English words), "Simulation RPG" -- it came about because the term "war simulation" was the genre term for war games in Japan, and for whatever reason the word "simulation" rather than "war" came to be used to abbreviate the genre. Then when they added named characters & experience points to it they called that a "Simulation RPG"

TRPG is an English abbreviation, "Tactical RPG" It came about because people thought SRPG stood for "Strategy RPG" and they didn't like that that didn't match the content of the games, which are about tactics. Either that or because Tactics Ogre and Final Fantasy Tactics were popular.

Of those three, I think the best game is Fire Emblem GBA (FE7). But Tactics Advance is really a much different beast, it has a larger focus on story and granular control over your individual units, with you training them up in various jobs and specializations much more similar to RPG games, whereas Fire Emblem is much more simply focused on being a war game, like chess or something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'd like to use a new term that applies to almost all FE games.

Puzzle Tactics game.

It's a "tactics" game where the emphasis is on "solving" a level by doing a very precise and rigid set of moves with very little room for improv.
To that end FE games tend to have side-objectives that emphasize rushing towards a part of the map where some unit is doing something on a "timer" so you have to immediately move a certain way with certain units to reach it. Also the weapon triangle makes it so very specific units can defeat other ones which are statically placed so you have to send a certain unit a certain way to accomplish that. Also the weapon triangle makes it so using a wrong unit can have them wiped out in even one attack, which reinforces the "correct" way of doing things and minimizes improv.

Games that would fit in this sub-genre are also Advanced Wars and (not retro) Into the Breach.

An example of a non-puzzle tactics game is Tactics Ogre, where you have more control over your party customization and loadout and the enemies can be defeated in a more fluid, back-and-forth way. Certain maps where you recruit special units are tailored mostly towards rushing them a specific way, but these are generally rare and special cases. In general you can flop around, lose some units, recover, and legitimately use "tactics" to win.
UFO and XCOM are also "true" tactics games.

>>9646353
>why are there so many tactics ogre/fft clones but so little fire emblem clones?
I suspect it's for the same reason that there are so many Castlevania clones and so few Metroid clones. Namely, that the majority of people don't fully appreciate the subtle differences between the two and so anyone asking for Metroid-like games is pointed toward Castlevania-like games as if it's all the same. Similarly, anyone who asks for Fire Emblem-like games is simply pointed to FFT-like games instead.

I think it comes from one game just being more popular than the other so that's what gets copied most and then people who don't respect the nuanced differences between the two don't drive any demand for copies of the less popular one because they don't even see a need for it.

>Well that's a perspective I've never heard before and does make the idea of just skipping to FE3 a lot more appealing.
If you only want to touch any form of that game once, then yes skip to Book 1 of Mystery of the Emblem. I will say there is a magic to FE1 that no other FE games have that I feel warrants at least one playthrough, though the inventory system might be frustrating to deal with as it is admittedly clunky. But there's a magic to playing the games in order of release and seeing the evolution there. Otherwise you would have to play half of a SNES game, go back to play Fire Emblem Gaiden on the NES, then go back for the other half of the SNES game to play in order of "1, 2, 3" for the games.
The inventory system might of the original Shadow Dragon might be frustrating to deal with, though. Even when the game wasn't even a year old yet there was an interview with the series creator on Famitsu and he talked about how people complained about that inventory system. So in the SNES remake he listened to the criticism and he overhauled it to be more easy to use and far less clunky.

>pinball physics

A pinball rolls on a flat surfaced and tilted table, a pinball is a heavy steel ball with no give and very little bounce, a pinball has no free movement of its own and is propelled by the various gadgets on the table (flippers, bumpers, pops, gravity).
Sonic is more akin to a fucking basketball or tennis ball that you can control mid-air and self propel, he runs he bounces he spins he can change his momentum mid bounce he does everything more than a simple pinball can.

Saying that Sonic the Hedgehog has pinball physics is fucking retarded, just because the game(s) incorporate ramps and flippers doesn't give it pinball physics. Sonic Spinball incorporates many pinball aspects but it is the farthest thing from representing the real physics of mother fucking pinball.

There's a lot of things that make the Sky Temple Keys awkward to collect. All the keys are in the dark world, which sucks to explore even after getting the light suit. The dark world is much more disconnected than the light world so you spend a lot of time going in and out of portals.

The hint system for those is clever though. There's always a fallen Luminoth Keybearer in the light world counterpart to the dark world room where the key is hidden. It makes things a little tougher than the Artifact Temple dishing out all the hints for free, but it does make the world feel a bit more thought-out.

>>9622582
Yes, the FOV in parts with pre rendered backgrounds is usually very big, with cameras far away from the characters.
This is why models are the way they are, there was no technical reason why they couldn't have used battle models outside of battles.

It is because they kept with the tradition of older FF games: all of them except 6 have closer FOV and more detailed characters in battle than they do in the world. They simply adapted that to 3D.

FF8 broke away from the tradition but as a result you have a much greater percentage of camera point of views that are closer to the characters, using scrolling backgrounds more when the characters move around.

>>9624513
This right here. I don't think it necessarily is a problem specific to random encounters either. It's a general problem with combat in story-centered JRPGs. What used to be the main part of the "story" in dungeon crawlers - i.e. you encounter an enemy that tries to kill you - is now turned into an obstacle that's in the way of the "real" story. By having so much linear scripted story it becomes more obvious that the random encounters aren't part of that story and it becomes just a chore you have to slog through.

The original PS had a metric shitload of games, and in spite of growing up with it, I never played THAT many games for it (had maybe 15 PS titles). Recently I've been revisiting the console and there have been a lot of fun lesser known games I've been playing.

Lucifer Ring is a sword and sorcery type 3D beat em up, a little basic and by the numbers, but some of the bosses are awesome and beat em ups in this old world setting aren't too common.

Brigandine is a very flavourful strategy game with a fantastic art direction and sense of style. I guess with games like Final Fantasy Tactics on the system, Brigandine was bound to be overlooked, but it really is great.

Also been playing Ape Escape. That's not really a niche title, but I've never played it before. It is very impressively polished and well thought out, just in general. I'm looking forward to checking out the other games in the series.

If you have any recommendations, let me know. Otherwise, just post about the PS below. PS2 is cool too.

I get what he’s saying. Growing up without really using the internet I didn’t even know there was a console war. I played gameboy and NES and later on N64 and Gameboy Color and then GameCube and Gameboy Advance then Wii and DS and I just never ran out of things to play. I also wasn’t exactly rich so I hardly even came close to playing everything. Looking back at PS1 and 2s vast library I nor any of my friends, even my well off ones, had even half the games on those lists and knew of maybe only a couple of the larger ones like Metal Gear Solid they never got. Comparing something retroactively to its potential versus its actuality is a bit foolish. Games were expensive when you were a kid, piracy hardly golden. Hell, one of my friends wanted to borrow a game to pirate a copy for himself and he ended up destroying my disk, so I was very piracy averse after that experience for years. If you want to compare and argue about it now potential matters, but I don’t think it matters when you actually talk about the reality of the situation. I didn’t know anyone who had Symphony of the Night growing up, nowadays it’s my second favorite Castlevania behind Rondo of Blood and only slightly beating out Castlevania 3. But I didn’t play any of these games before I was an adult, what I played growing up was was Castlevania 1 and 2 on my dads NES, and I didn’t play any of the ones on my N64 because. Well I never actually saw any at GameStop or at a yard sale. I played rogue squadron and army men and Mario and Zelda. My pals with their PlayStations played Spyro and Crash and a lot of shitty shovelware I don’t really remember (like army men Kek)

And we all played on our game boys and gameboy advances because that’s just what you did. We’d get the game links and play advance wars together or trade our Pokémon. Nintendo put out and published some fantastic games on their handhelds.

I mainly focused on playing the games and came to the conclusion that I thoroughly enjoyed all my consoles equally.

Handheld were judged on a different standard even back then.

Everyone considered handheld to be second rate games with a few exceptions such as pokemon or the igavanias. The worse graphics, but mostly

The games were also cheaper so that's another reason for the double standard.

Let's take RPGs as a illustration.FF7 stood for everything RPGs were transformed into: epic adventures with cinematic touches that brought story telling to realms that hadn't existed before. Sure you could bring up a good cutscene in games before ff7 but those were one offs, FF7 started epic and never stopped. Nothing on the gameboy could do that and we all knew it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653961
In terms of console versions (and ignoring the SoT-style remake >>9654094 >>9654885, which is basically a different game altogether), the only ones that have the original gameplay properly ported are the PC Engine, Sega CD and SNES versions. All others seem to just attempt to "recreate" it for some reason, with varying degrees of horribly misguided obtuseness. Regarding the good ones:

PC Engine and Sega CD (developed by the same Japanese studio) have some glitches and aren't visually great, but gameplay and layouts-wise are the closest to the original. Plus, you can actually set different playing speeds -slower or faster- for regular platforming and combat independently, which is neat for both novice and expert players. The developers included a very silly mistake though: the "hidden" floor switches lack the visual hint that should let you spot them easily. This is not critical and will never get you killed, but it's a weird slip given how accurate everything else is.

SNES (also Japanese-developed) is one of the most popular versions, but it's HEAVILY reinvented— except for the gameplay, which is almost perfectly accurate to the original. There's now roughly twice the levels, small changes in the original layouts, doubled time limit to compensate for the new scope, and brand new hazards and boss enemies. The bad side is that the latter boss fights clash a little with the constraints natural to the gameplay, and two or so of the original levels are missing due to the system's limitations regarding active elements per screen (slowdown is common as well when anything beyond one enemy is present in the screen). It's a great version, but I wouldn't consider it the "definitive" one.

rate the Phazon core, and seal it away. Believing that someday a savior
would return to the planet, the Chozo left for an unknown destination,
leaving behind nothing but engraved accounts of their time on Tallon IV

Despite all this, Chozo logs frequently mention Space Pirates and what they've done to Tallon IV. Who wrote these, if half the Chozo had ascended/fled elsewhere and the other half were schizophrenic ghosts who wandered the temples and attacked everything on sight? How did they write logs on things that hadn't happened yet? And if they're somehow watching Samus and influencing the writing she scans on walls, why don't they ever speak to her or celebrate the coming of The Child?

>>9647503
Total hyperzoomer opinion. In the 90s-2000s, you shipped a final game, and if it lived up to the sales expectations, the expansion pack you were already doing prelim work on didn’t get canceled. In the before times, if you shipped a game with a bug, you had to risk destroying your reputation and also incur huge costs by mailing out a fix to everyone who bought a copy. When the internet penetrated enough of the market, devs realized they could just put patches online for people to download—it was low cost and still an honest thing to do. It wasn’t until the late 2000s when (((developers))) and (((publishers))) figured out you could use digital distribution to ship broken/incomplete games, charge people $80 upfront, and then make them sit through “day 1” updates to play games for which they’d already paid. And then from there it was literally just a sleazy hop and jump to realize you could charge people $80 for half a game and sell the other half in 2 parts for $20 each, many months later. Add addictive grugbrain gambling on top of that and you arrive at AAA gaming in 2023. Give me CDs and shareware any day…

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9649897
Not sure about majority, it definitely varied.

>SC Broodwar
>AoE2: Age Of Conquerors
>Wolf3D : Nocturnal Missions
>Wolf3D : Spear Of Destiny
>DN3D : Atomic Edition
>Ultimate Doom
>Doom 3 : Resurrection Of Evil
>Extreme Rise Of The Triad
These were done in-house by the same devs.
Something like Ultimate Doom is like a quasi-expansion, the intent being that since Doom 2 was going to be a retail product instead of a mail-order one like the first game, if you were buying Doom 2, you could also grab the first one and get the full experience in one go, and there was a new episode of levels to give it more of a point. If you already had the mail order version you could get it upgraded to the retail version for free.

>HL : Opposing Force
>HL : Blue Shift
>Diablo Hellfire
>Wolf3D : Spear Of Destiny Pt. 2
>Wolf3D : Spear Of Destiny Pt. 3
>Quake : Dissolution Of Eternity
>Quake : Scourge Of Armagon
>Final Doom
>Master Levels Of Doom
>DN3D : Nuclear Winter
>DN3D : Duke It Out In D.C
>Duke Caribbean : Life's A Beach
These are ones developed by other devs in part or in full. For the Duke ones, NW is trash, D.C is ok, and Caribbean is excellent, all three were made by the same team at Sunstorm as I get, possibly with the exception of a level designer.
The Spear Of Destiny sequels are trash garbage, and FormGen did some stuff which iD didn't know at first, being forced to change it. Master Levels were like a crude handpick from submissions opened for the purpose (included Maximum Doom, a shovelware disc very much like the Wizard Works ones), while Final Doom was 50% a fan level pack which iD bought the rights to, and 50% two disgruntled brothers who worked on it making a chance offer to iD.
Hellfire, famously, were a third party making an offer to Blizzard, which the devs of Diablo largely REALLY didn't want, but didn't really get any say in. It's made in part from leftover dev assets already in the retail game's files, which were much nicer than Synergistic's own.

Um, yeah, no. Distributing fixes via mail was the way you did it before the internet. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9654543
Nah, kid. Doom released on December 10, 1993, as version 1.0, and version 1.1 came out less than one week later. Here's a link to the patch to update Doom v1.1 to v1.2, which was released online in February of 1994:
https://www.doomworld.com/idgames/historic/dm1_2rpt
The file is 441.12kb

Obviously, patches weren't as easy to distribute in these days, but it was absolutely done, and in a lot of cases it was a fairly small file which didn't take that much bandwidth to download, frequently these kinds of updates would be provided on included discs for some computer and gaming mags. That's not to mention software compilation discs/utility suites, or even regular old shovelware discs. If needed, you could go and use the internet connection of a school to download a patch and put it on a 3.5" floppy and then take it home, along with other stuff relevant to your game, or other games.

So depending on the game, you could very well see a problem it had getting patched without even having an internet connection at home, and Doom wasn't alone in that, if needed, patches could and would be distributed by mail.

posts.com: When purchasing some old bootleg Commodore games, I played on of the blank cartridges. It stood out because it turned out to be some Simpsons tie in game in which, for some reasons, I couldn't find on any info about it on any retrogaming site. The title of the game itself, "Large Marge & Bubble Bart" flashed in plain comic sans. It then showed some small clip demos of an isometric game, which involved someone vaguely looking like Marge Simpson and Bart in a bubble battling against clones of Nelson Muntzes and possum carcasses. I could only show you more screenshots next month after I finish moving.

>>9648096
I assume that the translators assumed the name was supposed to be GrandVALE instead of BELL because In Japanese there's no v sound so English names/words with v in them, that sound is replaced by a b sound. Similar to how l sounds get replaced with r sounds. That assumption often leads to names that really were supposed to be "Rhineford" as "Lineford" or Asparas as Aspallas. The same thing happens with v and b as well.

They are.

ドートレス = dootoresu = Daughtress
ドーントレス = doontoresu = dauntless

バリエント = bariento = Balient
バリアント = barianto = Valiant

ベルティゴ = berutigo = Bertigo

Names in Gundam are supposed to be either nonsensical or subtly off to emphasize the science fiction setting.

In Silent Hill 2 the sign above the hospital says "Blookhaven Hospital." Some Nip wrote that on the texture for it, yet something tells me whoever originally came up with the name almost certainly intended it to be "Brookhaven."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9651708
>old Chinese
Middle Chinese. Old Chinese is an even older predecessor.
>does Mandarin also have such problem?
No. The /ɾ/ sound in Japanese corresponds with /l/ in Mandarin, compare 蘭 (ran vs lan).
/nʲ/ and /ʑ/ in Japanese corresponds with /ɻ/ in Mandarin, which is very similar to the English r, compare 人 (nin/jin vs ren).
The major difference between the Chinese and English r sounds is that the English r is labialised (lips rounded), so the word "ran" would be pronounced differently in Chinese and English, but "ruan" would be pronounced almost identically, since the medial /u/ rounds the lips in Chinese.

>>9636792
>if you rewind before you got hit.. did you really learn how to dodge that attack?
Yes, because if you don't learn how to dodge it then you'll just get hit again and become stuck in a rewind loop until you learn how to not get hit. It's actually a much faster way to learn.

Without rewind, you either take the hit without dying and keep moving forward having learned little-to-nothing until next time or you die and restart the entire stage and have to replay until you get to the part where you died and try not to die.

With rewind, you get hit and then immediately rewind so you can analyze what hit you and why, then keep rewinding until you know exactly how to avoid it. It's the same practice loop as above, just done immediately instead of spread out over a long period of time.

>>9638054
The post I originally replied to literally says:
>i eventually learn to beat it because i'm picking up on stuff and applying learned muscle memory to this difficult situation.
Which is all much more quickly learned through immediate repetition. It's the difference between improving your free throw in basketball by throwing 100 free throws each day and improving your free throw by playing an entire game of basketball each day. One gives you distinctly fewer repetitions of what you're trying to improve. You need to practice the whole game, too, obviously, but these individual fundamental skills are best improved through maximum repetition. If you want to master dodging a specific boss's attack then the best thing you can do is rewind repeatedly until you've got all the cues and timings down. Practicing the game as a whole is a separate thing with a different practice method.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9640856
Is it mental gymnastics to say that throwing 100 free-throws in a row is better free-throw practice than playing an entire game of basketball? The latter will take significantly more time but offer significantly fewer chances for a free-throw. If you want to practice beating one specific section of a game, it's better and faster practice to repeat that section over and over than to restart the entire game each time.

To use a more video game oriented analogy, competitive fighting game players go into practice mode and repeatedly practice inputs for the same move or combo repeatedly for long stretches of time. That way when the pressure is on during a real game they're less likely to drop their inputs. Playing a whole match is also practice, but if you want to practice one move the best thing to do is just repeat it over and over, same goes for rewinding a single segment repeatedly until you have it down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In my opinion save states are only acceptable in the following circumstances:

- For NES era games that lack a saving function or credit system. Using a save state at the beginning of a world / set of levels instead of starting over from the very beginning.
- To suspend your game and pick up where you left off (like leaving your console on overnight)
- As a replacement for passwords as they can be a hassle to put in

Otherwise it's unacceptable. Rewinds are always unacceptable for obvious reasons, as there also isn't a cognitive learning process if you instantly rewind. Your brain won't learn the patterns like that, despite what some people claim here.

Fastforwarding in JRPG's is understandable, especially for the NES era. But I avoid them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653032
>Did it not occur to you while writing that training modes akshually make you worse
Not sure what you're referring to. All I know is that when you instantly rewind, there won't be a cognitive learning process as your brain needs to learn (adapt to) a certain pattern with expectations and outcomes. Rewinding just brings you back to the moment right before dying, but not the moments leading up to it. Yet you'll still receive the dopamine reward in both cases, taking away the motivation to become better at the game. Rewinding also drastically reduces the possibility of failure, and failure is when your brain actually learns in order to adapt and overcome. Hence the absence of learning.

8 and 16 bit games especially have been designed with this learning process in mind. It's the literal structure of those video games. When using save states or rewinds, you bypass this learning process and don't experience the game in full how it was intentionally designed by the brightest minds of the gaming industry. What you're left with is a powerpoint slide of dopamine shots that only serve as escapism. The element of 'play' almost completely disappears. Imagine soccer but every time a player misses he can rewind and slightly adjust his foot to make sure he'll get the right angle this time. What is left of the game then? Nothing.

In short, rewinding makes you a worse gamer in the long term. This is simple cognitive neurology, any scientist would agree. Save states and rewinds therefore make for an objectively inferior experience as you only experience a small aspect of the game. It's only slightly different than being a passive observer by watching a longplay on Youtube. It just baffled me how some people don't see this. I said my peace.

Well also remember that when Jenova was first found, Dr. Gast, and by extention Shinra, was under the impression that Jenova was a Cetra. Shinra's end goal was to create Neo Midgar by finding The Promised Land, a place with allegedly infinite Mako, and putting a reactor on top of it. And their goal with Jenova's corpse was to take cells from it and artificially create a human with the abilities of the Cetra. So the hybrid could speak to the Planet, point the way to The Promised Land, and Shinra could print infinite money. Which is just deranged. Imagine reading the Bible and getting to the scripture that speaks of Heaven having streets of gold. And rather than seeing that as God's promises to encourage you to get closer to God and reach a spiritual enlightenment, instead you decide to take the information you can find and make a lab baby that can possibly infiltrate heaven. Cloud does a lot of goofy shit even when he's LARPing as a soldier. Resorting to cross-dressing in order to fool a pimp is an intensely stupid idea. An actual Soldier who was employed by Shinra to put down resistance in an occupied Nation would balk at that idea. But Cloud isn't actually a soldier. So dolphin somersaults it is.

Just to avoid Poe's law I want to make it clear that I am not shitting on Cloud. I actually think it's good characterization. The goofy nature of the game ends up enhancing Cloud's character on repeat playthroughs when you realize that no sane person would tolerate half of Cloud's antics. And his biggest victory is just self-acceptance. Yeah Cloud is a dork but an extraordinarily determined one. One minute he's carving up WMDs created by the planet itself and the next minute he's complaining about motion sickness. He's a good character. Always has been.

>>9653101
I think the only way I can see your position is if you're considering "finish" to be distinct from "clear" or "beat". If that's not what it is then I don't understand your issue.
Many (not all) video games possess an end state. Score attack games have an end state; it's when the player has erred enough times. Competitive games have an end state; when one player wins or neither player is no longer eligible to win. Games focused on following a narrative have an end state; it's the conclusion of the story.
Generally games following a narrative place their credits after the conclusion of the story. This is a convention to notify the player they have finished the story and most likely the game itself. Exceptions exist but are not the common expectation.

Kirby's Star Stacker, the Pokemon games (including TCG), Space Invaders, Game & Watch games, that's probably it beyond Donkey Kong for games where they went all out.

Most of them you get a predefined four color palette that gets used by default and a custom border. Borders can range from meh to whoa too, most of them are rather simple, but some are dynamic. Pokemon TCG the border changes every single time you obtain a gym badge and they get displayed on the screen, looks good. Then there's Dragon Warrior Monsters, both games in the series change the border depending on the area you're currently in - so say if you're in a dungeon, you'll get dungeon walls around the gameplay area.

Oh and this has nothing to do with colors, but you might find this cool - I think all (if not all, then most) Takara fighting games allow you to play multiplayer with two SNES controllers.

Bomberman games, including the Wario one, do the same thing, but go a step further - you can actually use them with a multitap.

The real answer is it depends on a game by game basis. But both the Super Gameboy and Game Boy Color added different things, and it depends on the game to which one is the "superior" version.
For example Donkey Kong 94 was specifically designed for SGB, so it has specific colors for that and even audio. While the GBC has a predeterminde palette for DK94 it's nowhere as good as playing on SGB, it competely sucks in comparison.
For Pokemon TCG, the SGB palette is pretty good but if you play it on GBC, it's by far superior.
There are some games when sometimes the palette might be better on SGB while in other areas in GBC so no definitive version of which one to play, mostly preference.
Metroid 2 looks better on SGB but Mario Land 2 looks better on GBC, both were not made for either system but had designed palette.

>>9649669
>What SGB-enhanced games actually do full colorization like this and doesn't just put in a pre-set palette that sometimes changes as you play?

The Super GameBoy hardware is a bit limited when it comes to 'full colourization'. As far as I know, it can only display more than 4 colours on still images, like title screens and map screens. It has something to do with the way the SGB overlays colours. Also, I guess menu bars and anything 'static' can have additional colours. Games are limited to 4-colour palletes. But devs can assign different 4 colour palletes for different situations.

Some SGB games like Donkey Kong 94 add additional sound effect via the SNES audio chip.

Like Paulina saying 'Help!" is something you will not hear on a GameBoy.
https://youtu.be/jHN0yJuBVPM?t=138

Some SuperGameBoy games contain additional ROM's that run on the SNES:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rR5NY8vYWg4&t=106s

Some Super GameBoy games like Wario Blast have up to 4-player support with the SNES multi-tap and 3 extra controllers:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3gx1DAHCxiQ&t=40s

Street Fighter 2 has 2 player mode:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H3ipnCvpNF4

Battle Arena Toshinden has a two player mode:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=19q-j6PDfhk
>>9652294

>Anon, it's actually a bit faster than a DMG/GB/GBC.

The Super GameBoy is not completely accurate when it comes to playing GameBoy games. It overclocks every GameBoy game by 2.4%. This was a issue solved with the Super GameBoy 2, that was released in Japan only.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=alV7QTMewSA

The Super GameBoy came out before the GameBoy Colour by like 4 years. At the time, it was mostly advertised as a way to play GameBoy games on your TV. Game Boy Colour has a faster CPU and additional colour modes that the SGB can't replicate. So only the black cart GBC games work. The Game Boy Colour can add up to about 10 colours total to OG GB games. 4 for the BG layer 3 for both sprite layers.

It can split the gameboy screen into tiles and then give each tile its own 4 color palette, but it can't really change those very fast, which is why it's used primarily on stills.

You can see they had to compromise and make only a small section of Diddy's hat red because otherwise parts of his body would be red.

yeah, this. The only places you see more than 4 colors are the static title or menu screens and also HUD's in games. even DK Land 2 has an extra pallet just for the HUD. But the game portion is still using 4 colours total. But the 4 colours change with each stage.

https://youtu.be/yNJCanGOw9A?t=12

The GameBoy Color does have multiple palette options just like the GBA. But usually, it assigns a GB layer pallet and a foreground layer pallet, giving the game about seven colours total. But in some cases, the game might use two sprite layers. Like the HUD might be on its own layer, or maybe the main character might have its own layer. Like image related. This is a typical GBC default palette for Metroid II has a blue/ grey BG pallet, a red/ orange sprite pallet and a third green 'flashing' pallet. It has a pallet of ten colours.

https://youtu.be/4uIICjf4Ijo?list=PL17C81D7314CBFC7C&t=154 [Embed]

On Super Game Boy, it only adds 4-colours total. But it is easy to find a good 4-colour palette that works. The GBC looks better, IMO with the additional colours. But the Super GameBoy does overclock the game slightly. You can play Metroid II with an SNES gamepad.

Arbok gets glare, which is at least interesting. Plenty of options for poison for blue, not missing out. Sandshrew however is the best ground type pokemon in gen 1. Unless you go for speed abuse dugtrio. Cubone is solid too, but you get sandshrew earlier and it's better, so the winner Blue

Gloom getting petal dance makes it one of the best grass types in gen 1, weepinbell gets razor leaf, it's trash. Winner Red

Primeape is 2nd best fighting type in the game, getting one early in the game can be nice, persian is also possibly the 2nd best normal type, and has crit abuse and a great movepool so Tie.

Arcanine has fat stats, Ninetales has a few interesting moves, both fire, not really missing out over the other here another Tie

Pinsir vs Scyther, well, neither provide a counter to psychic. If we allow wing attack from yellow into play Scyther is the clear winner, otherwise its mostly a tie, but Id still edge scyther the winner since gets swords dance and such. So Red

Electabuzz and magmar both do the same thing. Just electric vs fire. I can't really call a winner here, so another tie. You don't get them in the same place, which is also interesting. One is in an area part of the main story, the other is not, but no major flaw or advantage on either.

Ultimately, red wins. I'll point out, if you want a grass type and you pick charmander or squirtle and play blue, you're fucked on grass, because bellsprout really sucks, petal dance vileplume is way better. Basically, scyther and vileplume clinch it for red. It's actually pretty balanced how they split it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think its interesting how all three starters have different playstyles that all manage to have different pros and cons so that none of them truly feel hard if you play different ways. even beyond the "Bulbasaur resists the first three gyms, Charmander is weak to the first 2(possibly 3 if you grind him to Charizard before Lt. surge)
Bulbasaur is great for defensive and stat changing/stalling play. Just the fact that he reissts a lot of common types and has a big spongey HP makes him perfect for the typical G1 grind method of "weak Pokemon first turn, then switch". also has a surprisingly high Special/attack, which means it can hold its own.Just solid for learning game mechanics.
Squirtle is a nice balanced middle ground between defense, special and attack, learns the biggest variety of moves and can cover most types buy itself.
Charmander feels the easiest to grind with because so much of what you encounter are bug types and Pokemon witha weak special stat ; while his attack/special aren't actually higher than the Bulbasaur line his move pool centers more around stronger attacks early on. Feels geared towards players who just want to use damaging moves.

You can beat the game largely with just one of any of them, sure, but I'd say Bulbasaur is the easiest to build a team around early on, Charmander is good for grinding through the early game if you just want to muscle through with attacks until you can take advantage of mid game Pokemon that become available, and Squirtle is best if you largely want to focus on one -three Pokemon. But you can easily use Charmander to solo the game, or Squirtle to build a team around.
Personally, when I want to not use a starter I usually go with Charmander to grind through with ember, get a nidoran as a support until I can lean more on him and get to Cerulean and have access to all the Pokemon around there.

posts.sub: Retro games that needed a remake/remaster but won't ever get it
posts.com:
It's a sad reality that the games that get remade...
- are already so good they are perfectly playable as they were
- are so well known they won't benefit from the extra exposure the remake provides
- are so beloved any minor changes will piss fans off
- are so historically important people will want to play the classic version anyway

This thread is instead for those games where a remake could be a game changer that will never happen, those games you see have something special and are full of unique potential but for one reason or another are not as good as they deserved to be. Post and discuss them

A JSRF remake or rerelease will never happen because the music rights are a nightmare. Most of the soundtrack (I believe all of the non-Naganuma tracks) was owned by a record label that went bust shortly after the game came out, and the rights went everywhere. >>9642142
it's kind of like translating Japanese to English. Shit is like a one to many situation all of the time simply because Japanese doesn't have a lot of ways to skin a cat (especially when compared to the nightmare gobblrfuck that is English) and so you could probably take a script in Japanese, give it to 5 different translators, and get 5 different translations, depending on all manner of things. Likewise, from a single blurry texture you could get 5 different interpretations by artists.

It's the problem of having to define one answer to an open question. It's like when gunpei yokoi defended using a black and white screen on the game boy. He said that if you draw two circles on top of each other on a whiteboard and say "it's a snowman" then people will fill the gaps in their mind of what the snowman looks like. Ask one artist to draw a detailed snowman to be "the" snowman in this, and someone observing it will say that it's not what they had imagined.

This is why movie adaptations of books can often seem off vs .the originals, because you read them and have an idea of what the characters look and sound like, all for it to be torn up when you see the Hollywood version where one team of (hopefully) interested people decided what every character and element would look like and would sound like and forced it upon everyone else.
It's also why Bill Watterson fought tooth and nail against merchandise for Calvin and Hobbes; He never wanted to get to the point of making a movie or tv show and having to decide what Hobbes' voice sounded like. That was for the reader to decide as they enjoyed the comic for themselves.

tl;dr a remake can basically never change graphics in any way without potentially alienating someone because there are too many ways to take something vague and turn it into something specific and inevitably, someone will like their own interpretation of it better.

I just beat Chrono Cross a few days ago and easily that game. It's not even hard to think of what to change either.
-spread all of the exposition dumps from the ending and from chronopolis throughout the entire game. make the time devourer clearly the antagonist earlier, reveal the FATE computer/Lynx earlier.
-remove terra tower coming to the main reality. just make the reptite empire a third dimension you have to go to at the end. it would be more satisfying than an asspull dungeon from nowhere.
-condense party members down to six (Magus, Ridelle, Nikki, Glenn, Korcha, Norris). despite having 40+ characters, there are only two major sidequests (Masamune stuff and Nikki's concert). add a sidequest for each of them.

you could make bigger changes if you were willing to flat out rewrite large chunks of it (I would roll leena and ridelle into being the same character and have her unaware of being Viper's daughter in the home universe) but without majorly rewriting the plot i think those are things that could make the game go from "good with serious issues" to "great". it's just so close to being a worthy sequel to trigger that it's frustrating that it willingly punches itself in the balls with its poor pacing and odd insistence on having so many recruitable party members despite doing nothing with them

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
idk much about racers ne we liked them desu but RR4 pulled me in i guess aesthetically. heard the theme and gave it a try. the aesthetic is cool, the tracks aren’t crazy, but do have a nice feel, i especially love the three night time stages. the interfaces, menus, music, and character portraits all have this energetic yet still laidback feel, captures that cowboy bebop or ray crisis combo of badass action with lively jazz going on. the drifting is easy and intuitive, i like how especially as a beginner you can catch on quickly, however the levels get more punishing of your mistakes. just as gilbert says by the end you’ll be trying to run the perfect race. speaking of gilbert one thing that really set R4 apart from every other racing game for me were the stories they’re nothing too deep, but they’re fun, simple, and the two middle ones, ESPECIALLY the PRC story do enough to grip you just enough to add a story motivation to the fun gameplay. that’s what captured me, but lll expose myself and say i’m a complete outsider. hydro thunder, NFS: HP, GT II, Wipeout, TOCA, i don’t play any of those shits, so maybe R4 is just the most accessible in that way. oh and most of the OST kicks ass

TLDR: cool ass menus, music, simple but serviceable characters, easy to learn, somewhat difficult to master gameplay, but im less than a noob to racers, so take it with a grain of salt.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9654628
Almost every thing you just stated was inaccurate

>Nearly perfect uniformity at will
Same weaknesses here as direct view.
>Nearly perfect geometry at will
lmao. Even with the best calibrated set-up you're still going to have some perspective errors due to the way your house is built, wall is warped, screen is not angled exactly right, etc. Strictly worse than direct view.
>lightbleed
Same weaknesses as direct view PLUS you have to deal now with ambient light on your screen.
>no gridlines
LCD projectors are famous for their screen-door effect. Higher resolution helps but to say it doesn't exist is a lie.
>no blooming
Screen material absolutely can cause this as well as hot spots.
>extremely low input lag
Same amount as direct view, being a projector doesn't really come into play here
>much cheaper
Debatable since there are some fuck-huge LCDs available now that have made their way onto the used market for < $500
>no smearing
Just false, man. Same issue as the direct view technology the projector shares.
>no blur
see above, going to have plenty of it on an LCD projector. Less on LCOS. Maybe even less on laser-hybrid. But it's not going to be zero. Plus you have to focus your projector, and you're always going to have softer focus around the edges of the screen. That's just the nature of the technology.
>no ghosting
see above. Projectors aren't really that much different than the technology used in direct view.

Game is hoarded. Gets leaked. Hoarder (BakuDD) upset. Mirrored everywhere.
A few years later... Fake name with nonexistent Argentinian address and online lawyer service successfully gets UK trademark for the logo, files for more trademarks on the logo, merchandise, and even the source code.

Those mirrors are immediately targeted and taken down, then videos and tweets and everything about the game. But anything on the Japanese net is fine. Some articles are posted about it. Vinesauce does a video playthrough. Gets /v/ attention, game is mirrored and tons of new videos are made. At this point, copyright troll reads on /v/ that the game has some devs who joined Nintendo later. So he files new takedowns as NINTENDO. He stops for a while. BakuDD crawls out of his basement and denies it's him.
Then he takes down everything except a couple of videos with the most views, biding his time until it all dies down. This time as Ukie, an ESA-type organisation but for the UK.

Some discussion about the lost OST and RODIK websites and datamining happens on /v/. A translation is discussed.

Cue Discord.

Some from the "official Discord server for Cookie Bustle" come to /v/ and announce they're taking care of the translation, and shilling their server. Their invite is present in this video too >>9627917
Discussion about that project fizzles out from /v/ .
In the discord server proper, some progress happens for adding subtitles in the game for the spoken lines and disabling the serial code. They don't have many Japanese translators either.

Turns out:
- BakuDD is in that server
- Apologists for the copyright troll successfully coopted the server
- They also subverted the translation project so that nothing about it being a non-commercial project or anything about RODIK is mentioned because "RODIK aren't the owners of Cookie's Bustle", and want the English translation project to continue in a state the troll (supposed "legit owner of the source code") can sell.

You're here

>>9628150
It's a bit of an inbetween.
The game isn't bad, it has quirky dark humour tipical from late 90's Japan, it has a distinct PC game graphic style from the time.
It's not bad, it's not average, it does its job well.
The thing that usually attracts people is the nature of the world itself, how adorable Cookie is that triggers in some people some kind of parental instinct to protect her from this dumb world she finds herself in, the music is really good and catchy and it's overall a charming experience.
I wouldn't call it a hidden gem, but it IS an interesting game.

https://boingboing.net/2019/11/18/horace-goes-copyright-striking.html

One example I can think of is Paul Andrews, who is part of a few companies like Retro Games Ltd and Subvert. Responsible for some re-releases of Lynx and microcomputer games. He seems to have made whatever pittance of a licensing agreement you need to with whatever legacy publisher notionally owns some relevant (but not very scrutinized) rights to some random old ZX Spectrum and C64 games which are not exactly hot commodities. You know, for the license to republish, maybe issue a "remake".

One of the more notable examples of this is that his company/companies "own" the rights to the Horace games on ZX Spectrum. A few years back he went on a tear, launching copyright takedowns for anything featuring Horace that he didn't like, including videos by some YouTuber whose content he felt "undermined Horace's family-friendly image." Further scrutiny suggests that the actual rights are murky at best far more limited than he suggests, meaning he likely doesn't even have the right to copyright strike anything. But hey, it's Horace, who's gonna put the money in to litigate against that?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653016
It's not hard to make a Mame machine. But it's time consuming and the experience isn't the same as it was back in the 90s.

Arcade cabs usually had 1 game (unless it was a Neo Geo). And it played instantly when you dropped a quarter it in. No wait times or scrolling through tons of menus.

With Mame, people put thousands of games on their MAME machines. You walk up to a Mame machine and you can spend 10 minutes just scrolling through menus. Annoying and It really kills the vibe.

Plus you need to download roms, setup mame, fiddle with settings (which can take hours or days), test everything, tweak the controls to your likeing, and install a front-end (the pretty menu that you scroll through when choosing a game).

And worst of all, everytime Mame updates you need to re-download all your Roms again because the roms aren't compatible with the new version. I don't know why they haven't figured out a better way. If there's an error, then you deal with a lot Mame elitists who insult you and claim your an idiot. Even though Mame looks like it's still stuck in the era Windows 98. They havent updated their UI in decades.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9653426
I've spoken with many old school arcade operators. I can offer some of their thoughts.

Some arcade machines kept track of how much they earned in the hidden operator test settings. Data would display on how much money/quarters that players put inside the machine on each difficulty. You could track the data.

If you made the difficulty too high, then casual players would give up and stop playing because it was too hard.

If you made it too easy, then the game wouldn't be seen as a challenge and your casual players would easily beat the on less quarters. Which means you earn less money.

The idea was to find the perfect middle ground. You could adjust default CPU difficulty on a scale from level 1 to level 10 in many games.

If your arcade was in an area with mostly casual players and children, then you kept the difficulty on moderate. You go easy on the kids to lure more quarters out of them. Give them just enough hope and they will give you more quarters.

For an arcade that had a lot of "pro players", operators kept the difficulty on high because they would be more of a challenge to pro players.

For some games like Fighting games, you could even adjust the default damage level.

For example, in the Philippines the the damage level was actually kept on 50% instead of the normal 100%. Kids didn't have a lot of money, so arcade owners would lower the damage so the players that visited often would be able to "feel" like they got their money's worth. Matches would be extra long due to lower damage. But this kept visitors coming to arcades. This happened in many countries in Asia, South America, and the Pacific Islands where kids had less money.

In America and Europe the damage was set to 100%

This led to an interesting scenario in "Marvel VS Capcom 2" when they were trying to host worldwide tournaments. Players argued on what should be the default damage level. Players spend their whole careers being used to a specific damage level.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653543
>This led to an interesting scenario in "Marvel VS Capcom 2" when they were trying to host worldwide tournaments. Players argued on what should be the default damage level. Players spend their whole careers being used to a specific damage level.

Part 2 - Continued

There was some arguments and debates on what should be the default damage level for worldwide Marvel VS Capcom tournaments.

As an Asian/Filipino/South American player, if you spent hundreds of hours (or even a few thousand hours) learning to play your team on a lower damage setting then your whole play style revolves around that damage levels. You know how EXACTLY much damage your character can take but still survive. Or How to recover, counter, etc. It will be very difficult to adjust to higher damage.

For players in America and Europe, you've trained your muscle memory to be able to execute the combos you need to exactly kill the enemy team with damage level set to 100%. If the damage level is set to 50%, then suddenly your combos that would kill the enemy team will still leave them alive.

So there were debates and arguments between players about it. I think the American Players and European players won out because... Well they are richer and put more money into hosting the tournaments. So they decided the rules.

>Question for those who knew arcade operators personally:
>What was the general standard for setting the difficulty on arcade games?

It depended on the owner or manager. They decided how much money they could milk the players for. Could be medium. Could be hard.

>Did they even bother to change anything from factory settings?

Oh yeah. Everything was changed. Fun fact.

Lightgun games have an hidden option called "Time to Death." Basically it guarantees the player will be hit X amount of times no matter what.

Ever play House of the Dead and get hit by a zombie that you SWORE you shot its head off...but it hit you anyway before falling? That's the game setting I'm talking about. It guarantees a hit on the player. The operator can decide, no matter how skilled you are, that you will die by a certain point in the game no matter what you do. The only way is to put more quarters in.
